IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: Detailed Crash investigation Supplement (For review by the MSP Crash Team) Narrative On 8/19/2023, at approximately 2209 hours, I, TFC Cambra #7191, an Advanced Collision Investigator (ACI) assigned to the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack was requested by the Maryland State Police Princess Anne Barrack to respond to the area of North Bound US-13 and Spring Lane in reference to a collision involving a single vehicle and a pedestrian. I was advised the pedestrian was being flow by Maryland State Police Aviation Trooper 4 to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma for treatment to their life-threatening injuries. I arrived on scene at approximately 2308 hours. I made contact with Trooper Wright #7521 who was the primary investigator on scene where I learned the following: Vehicle #1 2009 Black Honda Civic, New Jersey Registration P27MRH Driver: Monica Laticia Reaves (DOB:03/27/1969 1/F) Passenger: Tara M Foeman (11/16/1968 1/F) Pedestrian Identified by Mexican ID card Franco Simon Garcia (DOB: 02/18/1996 5/M) Garcia was leaving the Goose Creek Convenient located at 9010 Ocean Highway (US-13), Westover, MD, 21871,and attempted to run across the north Bound lane of US-13 Garcia was with a friend/witness while running across the road The individual was described as 54, 55, short brown hair, Aqua T-Shirt, Camo Pants, Flip Flops, and carrying a case of beer Vehicle #1 was traveling north in lane #2 when the front driver side of vehicle #1 struck the pedestrian Garcia landed between lane #1 and lane #2 margin-bottom:11px">Vehicle #1 came to rest at the intersection of northbound US-13 and Spring Lane Garcia was flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma for treatment to life threatening injuries that he sustained. It was noted that Garcia was potentially under the influence of alcohol. The roadway was illuminated from lights from the Goose Creek Convenient Store and near by Street lights however, a single street lamp prior to the area of impact functioned only part of the time on scene. There were periods of the light being operational and periods of it being non-operational. Scene Processing I documented the scene thoroughly taking digital photographs of the involved vehicle and area of impact. I marked any pertinent roadway evidence utilizing fluorescent orange paint. I conducted an interview of Reeves who stated the following: They were traveling in the far-right lane (Slow lane) As they get to the gas station, they saw two men run across the street She hit her horn as both men kept running She swerved to the right and he ran into my car and the other man left the scene She pulled over By the time you could see the them, they were on the dotted broken line in the middle of the roadway Neither one of them stop They came into the roadway by the Do Not Enter Sign One individual was shirtless, and one had his back towards them The pedestrians didnt look and they were running they are runnin across the street and playin with each other There was another car next to her in the fast lane, no other car stopped margin-bottom:11px">Both the driver and passenger completed a written statement I observed no roadway evidence prior to the area of impact. The area of impact was found a few feet South of Spring Lane. I observed Garcias shoes to be in Lane #2 in the Northbound lane of US-13. I also observed blood in the roadway to be on the solid white line between lane #2 and the right turn lane. The front driver side fog lamp cover of vehicle #1 was found in the roadway. I observed scrapes on the black paint above the front driver side tire. The lower portion of the front windshield on the driver side was cracked with a small amount of blood on the glass. The driver side, side view mirror was damaged and hanging from the wire. I observed an inward dent on the driver side front quarter panel in front of the driver side door. I continued to observe scrapes of the paint down the driver side of the driver side to the rear driver side quarter panel. Conclusion On 08/19/2023, Troopers from the Maryland State Police Princess Anne Barrack responded to a report of a vehicle vs pedestrian collision on northbound US-13 at Spring Lane, Somerset County, Maryland. Upon arrival, Troopers identified the pedestrian by a Mexican ID card as Franco Simon Garcia (DOB: 02/18/1996 5/M). The involved vehicle was found to be a black 2009 Honda Civic bearing New Jersey registration P27MRH, operated by Monica Laticia Reaves (DOB:03/27/1969 1/F). Garcia entered the northbound lanes of US-13, in a location not marked for pedestrians to cross, in dark conditions. While nearly halfway through the roadway, the Civic traveling in lane #2, attempted to avoid striking Garcia, however Garcia continued to run east. Subsequently, the front of the Civic struck Garcia between lane #2 and the right turn lane on North Bound US-13. Garcia proceeded to roll down the driver side of the vehicle, striking the front windshield. Garcia subsequently landed on the roadway between lane #2 and the right turn lane. Based on the damage on the vehicle, location of the area of impact, and statements made by the driver, it appeared as if Garcia was struck by the front driver side of the Civic and then proceeded to seemingly roll down the side of the vehicle before landing on the ground. Based on the fact Garcia and the pedestrian had a case of beer and the lack of reaction to an oncoming vehicle, it is likely that Garcia was under the influence of alcohol when entering the roadway. Garcia received emergency medical treatment and was transported to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma for treatment for his injuries. The pedestrian that was with Garcia was located in a nearby in a farm. He was identified as Marcelino Arason Carrero. Carrero was located by additional Troopers on scene. CCTV from Goose Creek Convenient Store was watched observed by additional units on scene which provided the description of Carrero. A nearby business, RW Motors was not equipped with any CCTV. The Civic did not have any airbag deployment as a result of the collision. Based on the collision, the vehicle was released from the scene to Reaves. All necessary measurements were taken on scene. The roadway was washed off and reopened at 0116 hours. Later that evening, I contacted the University of Maryland Shock Trauma and was advised that Garcia was in critical condition. On 8/21/2023, I contacted the University of Maryland Shock Trauma again and I was advised that Garcia was critical but stable. I continued to check in with the University of Maryland Shock Trauma for updates to Garcia. On 10/1/2023, I was advised Garcia is still receiving treatment from the University of Maryland TBI unit. Due to Garcia suffering non-life-threatening injuries, it was determined that there was no further need to complete a collision reconstruction. This supplement is to be used by Trooper Wright for any additional information for his investigation. TFC N. Cambra #7191 Maryland State Police Easton Barrack 7053 Ocean Gateway Easton, Maryland 21601 410-822-3101
